Key Arguments: The proposed legislation is ethically wrong as it suppresses the fundamental right to free expression.
The legislation will lead to unintended consequences, such as driving users to unregulated international platforms.
The definition of harm in the bill is excessively broad, leading to potential suppression of legitimate discourse.
Social media platforms are not equipped to fairly police misinformation due to potential biases and lack of local context.
The legislation could entrench the market position of legacy media and limit competition.
The proposed approach is likely to be counterproductive and not achieve its intended goals.
Main Themes: Ethical concerns about free speech and censorship
Criticism of the broad and vague definitions of harm
Skepticism about the effectiveness of the legislation
Concerns about the role of foreign-owned platforms in content moderation
Notable Quotes: I believe it is a fundamental right of all people to publicly express their views and opinion on all matters.
The legislation will cause a suppression of legitimate views, and thus be unethical.
I am sceptical that the legislation will have a substantial effect on reducing the spread of misinformation.

The bill obliges social media platforms to censor posts that have the potential to cause serious harm. While this sounds like a worthwhile objective, the definition of harm in the bill is excessively wide.
